snippet: More than 35,000 dairy cows died after a two-day storm hit West Texas and New Mexico on Dec. 26, leaving farmers unable to reach them amid gusts of 80 miles per hour and 14-foot snow drifts.
abstract: More than 35,000 dairy cows have died in blizzard that swept acrossTexas and New Mexico, for two days, leaving snow drifts up to 14 feet high and keeping farmers from reaching their herds for days; many cattle have developed frostbite and could still die; states are encouraging farmers to report their losses to the federal government and apply for emergency assistance, including loans.

byline.original: By LUCINDA HOLT and FERNANDA SANTOS
byline.contributor: Lucinda Holt reported from Lubbock, and Fernanda Santos from Phoenix.

lead_paragraph: More than 35,000 dairy cows died after a two-day storm hit West Texas and New Mexico on Dec. 26, leaving farmers unable to reach them amid gusts of 80 miles per hour and 14-foot snow drifts.

headline.main: Blizzard Buried Some Dairy Cows in the Snow; 35,000 Die
headline.print_headline: A Deathly Chill in the Fields
